text: The Lord spoke to Moses in the Sinai desert, in the meeting tent on the first day of the second month, in the second year after they had come out of the land of Egypt. The Lord said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Number all the people of Israel, by their families, by those of their fathers’ houses. Write down the names of every male, head by head,
speaker: Narrator

text: twenty years old and older. You and Aaron number by their armies whoever in Israel is able to go out to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man from each family should be with you to help you. Each one should be the head of his father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the men who will help you: Shedeur’s son Elizur from Reuben,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zurishaddai’s son Shelumiel from Simeon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Amminadab’s son Nahshon from Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zuar’s son Nethanel from Issachar,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Helon’s son Eliab from Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the sons of Joseph there will be Ammihud’s son Elishama from Ephraim, and Pedahzur’s son Gamaliel from Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be Gideoni’s son Abidan from Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ammishaddai’s son Ahiezer from Dan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ochran’s son Pagiel from Asher,
speaker: Narrator

text: Deuel’s son Eliasaph from Gad,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Enan’s son Ahira from Naphtali.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the ones chosen from the people. They were the leaders of their fathers’ families, the heads of thousands in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron took these men who had been chosen by name.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they gathered all the people together on the first day of the second month. The people gave their names by families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names from twenty years old and older, head by head.
speaker: Narrator

text: They did just as the Lord had told Moses. So he numbered them in the desert of Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Reuben, Israel’s first-born, were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of the family of Reuben was 46,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Simeon were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of the family of Simeon was 59,300.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Gad were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of the family of Gad was 45,650.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Judah were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of the family of Judah was 74,600.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Issachar were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of the family of Issachar was 54,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Zebulun were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of the family of Zebulun was 57,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Joseph, the sons of Ephraim, were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of the family of Ephraim was 40,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Manasseh were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of the family of Manasseh was 32,200.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Benjamin were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of the family of Benjamin was 35,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Dan were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of the family of Dan was 62,700.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Asher were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of the family of Asher was 41,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Naphtali were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of the family of Naphtali was 53,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were numbered by Moses and Aaron, and the leaders of Israel, twelve men, each chosen from his father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men of Israel were numbered by their fathers’ houses, twenty years old and older, whoever in Israel was able to go out to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of all the men was 603,550.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Levites by their fathers’ family were not numbered with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had told Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Only the family of Levi should not be numbered. Do not add their number among the sons of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But have the Levites take care of the meeting tent of the Law, and all that is in it, and all that belongs to it. They will carry the meeting tent and all that goes in it. They will take care of it, and set up their tents around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the meeting tent is to be moved, the Levites will take it down. When the meeting tent is brought to a place to stay, the Levites will set it up. If anyone else comes near, he must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel will set up their tents by their own groups and armies, each man by his own flag.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Levites will set up their tents around the meeting tent of the Law. Then no anger will come upon the people of Israel. The Levites must take care of the meeting tent of the Law.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people of Israel did this. They did everything the Lord had told Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The people of Israel will set up their tents, each by his own flag and beside that of their fathers’. They will set up their tents to face the meeting tent on every side.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who stay in their tents on the east side toward the sunrise will have the flag of Judah by their armies. The leader of the people of Judah is Nahshon the son of Amminadab.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of all his army is 74,600.
speaker: Narrator

text: The family of Issachar will set up their tents next to Judah. The leader of the people of Issachar is Nethanel the son of Zuar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of his army is 54,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The family of Zebulun will be next. The leader of the people of Zebulun is Eliab the son of Helon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of his army is 57,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole number among the tents of Judah is 186,400, by their armies. They will be first to move on.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the south side will be the tents of Reuben by their armies with their flags. The leader of the people of Reuben is Elizur the son of Shedeur.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of his army is 46,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The family of Simeon will set up their tents next to him. The leader of the people of Simeon is Shelumiel the son of Zurishaddai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of his army is 59,300.
speaker: Narrator

text: The family of Gad will be next. The leader of the people of Gad is Eliasaph the son of Deuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of his army is 45,650.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole number among the tents of Reuben is 151,450 by their armies. They will be second to move on.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the meeting tent will go out with the Levites among the people. In the same way that they set up their tents, so they will leave to move on, every man in his place, by his flags.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the west side will be the flag of the tents of Ephraim by their armies. The leader of the people of Ephraim is Elishama the son of Ammihud.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of his army is 40,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The family of Manasseh will be next to him. The leader of the people of Manasseh is Gamaliel the son of Pedahzur.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of his army is 32,200.
speaker: Narrator

text: The family of Benjamin will be next. The leader of the people of Benjamin is Abidan the son of Gideoni.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of his army is 35,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole number among the tents of Ephraim is 108,100, by their armies. They will be third to move on.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the north side will be the flag of the tents of Dan by their armies. The leader of the people of Dan is Ahiezer the son of Ammishaddai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of his army is 62,700.
speaker: Narrator

text: The family of Asher will set up their tents next to him. The leader of the people of Asher is Pagiel the son of Ochran.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of his army is 41,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The family of Naphtali will be next. The leader of the people of Naphtali is Ahira the son of Enan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of his army is 53,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole number among the tents of Dan is 157,600. They will be last to move on with their flags.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the numbers of the men of Israel by their fathers’ houses. The whole number among all the tents, by their armies, was 603,550.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Levites were not numbered with the people of Israel, just as the Lord had told Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people of Israel did all that the Lord had told Moses. They set up their tents by their flags. And they left to move on in the same way, every one by his family and by his father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the people of Aaron and Moses at the time when the Lord spoke with Moses on Mount Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The names of the sons of Aaron are Nadab the first-born, Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the sons of Aaron, the chosen religious leaders. Aaron set them apart to work as religious leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Nadab and Abihu died before the Lord when they made a fire that was not holy to the Lord in the Desert of Sinai. And they had no children. So Eleazar and Ithamar worked as religious leaders during the life-time of their father Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Bring the family of Levi near. Set them in front of Aaron the religious leader so they may serve him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will do the duties for him and for all the people in front of the meeting tent. They will do the work around the meeting tent,
speaker: Narrator

text: and will keep all the things that belong to the meeting tent. They will take care of the duties for the people of Israel as they work around the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will give the Levites to Aaron and his sons. They are all given to him from among the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Set apart Aaron and his sons to do the work of religious leaders. But if anyone comes near who is not a religious leader, he must be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “See, I have taken the Levites from among the people of Israel instead of every first-born among the people of Israel. The Levites will be Mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all the first-born are Mine. On the day that I killed all the first-born in the land of Egypt, I set apart for My own all the first-born in Israel, both man and animal. They will be Mine. I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses in the Desert of Sinai,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Number the sons of Levi by their fathers’ houses and by their families. Number every male a month old and older.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses numbered them just as he had been told by the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The names of the sons of Levi are Gershon, Kohath and Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: The names of the sons of Gershon by their families are Libni and Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Kohath by their families are Amram, Izhar, Hebron and Uzziel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Merari by their families are Mahli and Mushi. These are the families of the Levites by their fathers’ houses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of Gershon were the families of the Libnites and the Shimeites. These were the families of the Gershonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of their men, every male a month old and older, was 7,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families of the Gershonites were to set up their tents behind the meeting tent on the west side.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leader of the fathers’ houses of the Gershonites was Eliasaph the son of Lael.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Gershon were to take care of the meeting tent, its covering, and the curtain for the door of the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they were to take care of the curtains for the door of the open space, and all curtains around the meeting tent and the altar and their ropes. They did all the work having to do with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of Kohath were the families of the Amramites, the Izharites, the Hebronites and the Uzzielites. These were the families of the Kohathites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of every male a month old and older was 8,600. They did the duties of the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families of the sons of Kohath were to set up their tents on the south side of the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leader of the fathers’ houses of the Kohathite families was Elizaphan the son of Uzziel.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took care of the special box with the Law, and the table, the lamp-stand, the altars, the things used in the holy place, and the curtain. They did all the work having to do with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eleazar, the son of Aaron the religious leader, was the head of the leaders of Levi. He watched over those who did the duties of the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of Merari were the families of the Mahlites and the Mushites. These were the families of Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of their men, every male a month old and older, was 6,200.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leader of the fathers’ houses of the families of Merari was Zuriel the son of Abihail. They were to set up their tents on the north side of the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: The duties given to the sons of Merari were to take care of the parts made of wood of the meeting tent, its cross pieces, its pillars, its bases, and all the pieces that had to do with them. They took care of all these things,
speaker: Narrator

text: and of the pillars around the open space and their bases and their nails and their ropes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron and his sons were to set up their tents on the east side in front of the meeting tent, toward the sunrise. They did the duties of the meeting tent, whatever had to be done for the people of Israel. But the one who came near who was not a religious leader was to be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of all the Levite men a month old and older, whom Moses and Aaron numbered by their families as the Lord told them, was 22,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Number every first-born male of the sons of Israel a month old and older. Write down their names.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the Levites for Me, instead of all the first-born among the sons of Israel. I am the Lord. And take the cattle of the Levites instead of all the first-born among the cattle of the people of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses numbered all the first-born among the sons of Israel, just as the Lord had told him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of names of all the first-born males a month old and older was 22,273.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the Levites instead of all the first-born sons of Israel, and the cattle of the Levites. The number of the Levites will be Mine. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are 273 first-born of the sons of Israel, who are more in number than the Levites. You must pay the price for each of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take five pieces of silver for each, by the weight of silver agreed upon for the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give the money, the price of those who are more in number than the Levites, to Aaron and his sons.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses took the money to pay for those who were more in number than the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took the money from the first-born sons of Israel, by the weight agreed upon for the meeting tent. He took 1,365 pieces of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses gave the money to Aaron and his sons, just as the Lord had told Moses by His Word.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Number the sons of Kohath from among the sons of Levi. Number them by their families, by the fathers’ houses,
speaker: Narrator

text: from thirty years old and older, even to fifty years old. Number all who are able to do the work in the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the work of the sons of Kohath in the meeting tent to do with the most holy things.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people leave to move on, Aaron and his sons will go in and take down the curtain in front of the special box with the Law inside. And they will cover the special box with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will lay a covering of badgers’ skins on it, and spread a pure blue cloth over that. And they will put in the long pieces of wood to carry it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will spread a blue cloth over the table of the bread before the Lord. They will put on it the plates, the dishes for special perfume, the pots, and the jars for the drink gift. And the bread will be on it always.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will spread a red cloth over them, and cover that with badgers’ skins. And they will put in its long pieces of wood to carry it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will take a blue cloth and cover the lamp-stand for the light, with its lamps, its objects to put out the light, its dishes and all its pots of oil used for the light.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will put the lamp-stand and all its objects in a covering of badgers’ skins. Then they will put it on the long pieces of wood used to carry it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will spread a blue cloth over the altar of gold, and cover it with badgers’ skins. And they will put in the long pieces of wood to carry it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will take all the things used for the work done in the meeting tent. They will put them in a blue cloth and cover them with a covering of badgers’ skins. And they will put them on the long pieces of wood to carry them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will take away the ashes from the altar, and spread a purple cloth over it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will put on it all the things used for the work done on the altar: the fire-holders, meat-hooks, objects for picking up the ashes, and the pots. Then they will spread a covering of badgers’ skins over it, and put in the long pieces of wood for carrying it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron and his sons will finish covering the holy objects and all the things of the meeting tent, as the people move on. After that the sons of Kohath will come to carry them. In this way they will not touch the holy objects and die. These are the things in the meeting tent which the sons of Kohath are to carry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eleazar the son of Aaron the religious leader will take care of the oil for the light, the special perfume, the grain gift which is always given, and the oil for holy use. He will watch over all the meeting tent and all that is in it, the holy place and its objects.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not let the family group of the Kohathites be destroyed from among the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: But do this to them so they may live and not die when they come near the most holy objects. Aaron and his sons must go in and give each of them their work and what they are to carry.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they must not go in to see the holy objects even for a short time, or they will die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Number the sons of Gershon also, by their fathers’ houses, by their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: Number those who are thirty years old and older, to fifty years old, all who go in to do the work in the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the duties of the families of the Gershonites, in working and in carrying.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will carry the curtains of the meeting tent and the meeting tent with its covering and the covering of badgers’ skins that is over it. They will carry the curtain for the door of the meeting tent,
speaker: Narrator

text: the curtains of the open space, and the curtain for the gate of the open space which is around the meeting tent and the altar. And they will carry the ropes for the curtains, and all the things used for their work. They will do whatever needs to be done with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the work of the sons of the Gershonites will be what Aaron and his sons tell them to do. They will tell them what they are to carry and what work they are to do. You will tell them what things they have a duty to carry.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the work to be done by the families of the sons of the Gershonites in the meeting tent. Ithamar the son of Aaron the religious leader will watch over their duties.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for the sons of Merari, number them by their families and by their fathers’ houses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Number those who are thirty years old and older, to fifty years old, everyone who goes in to do the work of the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what they are to carry for their work in the meeting tent: the wood pieces of the meeting tent, its cross pieces, pillars and its bases.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they are to carry the pillars which are around the open space and their bases and their nails and ropes, with all the things used for their work. You will tell each man by name what he is to carry.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the work of the families of the sons of Merari, all their work in the meeting tent. Ithamar the son of Aaron the religious leader will watch over their duties.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron and the leaders of the people numbered the sons of the Kohathites by their families and by their fathers’ houses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They numbered those who were thirty years old and older, to fifty years old, everyone who went in to do the work in the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: And their number by families was 2,750.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the numbered men of the Kohathite families, everyone who worked in the meeting tent. Moses and Aaron numbered them as the Lord told them to do through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Gershon were numbered, by their families and their fathers’ houses,
speaker: Narrator

text: from thirty years old to fifty years old. Everyone who went in to do the work in the meeting tent was numbered.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the number of their men by their families and by their fathers’ houses was 2,630.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the numbered men of the families of the sons of Gershon, all who were working in the meeting tent. Moses and Aaron numbered them as the Lord told them to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of the families of the sons of Merari were numbered, by their families and their fathers’ houses,
speaker: Narrator

text: from thirty years old to fifty years old. Everyone who went in to do the work in the meeting tent was numbered.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the number of their men by their families was 3,200.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the numbered men of the families of the sons of Merari. Moses and Aaron numbered them as the Lord told them to do through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron and the leaders of Israel numbered all the men of the Levites by their families and their fathers’ houses,
speaker: Narrator

text: from thirty years old to fifty years old. Everyone who could go in to do the work and the carrying of the meeting tent was numbered.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the number of their men was 8,580.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were each given their work and load to carry, as the Lord told them to do through Moses. So these were his numbered men, just as the Lord had told Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the people of Israel to send away from the tents every person with a bad skin disease, every one with a flow that is unclean, and every one who is unclean because of a dead person.
speaker: Narrator

text: Send away both male and female. Send them away from the tents so they will not make the place sinful where I live among them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel did so. They sent them away from the tents. The people of Israel did just as the Lord had said to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘When a man or woman sins the way that man sins by not acting in faith toward the Lord, and that person is guilty,
speaker: Narrator

text: then he must tell about the sins he has done. He must pay in full for his wrong-doing, and add one-fifth part to it, and give it to the one he has sinned against.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the man has no brother to whom pay for the wrong can be made, then it must go to the Lord for the religious leader. He must also give a ram to pay for his sins. And his sins will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every gift of all the holy things of the Israelites which they bring to the religious leader will become his.
speaker: Narrator

text: So every man’s holy gifts will be his. Whatever any man gives to the religious leader will be his.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘If a man’s wife turns away and is not faithful to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and another man has sex with her and it is hidden from her husband’s eyes, even if it is hidden, she will be unclean. And even if no one speaks against her, because she has not been caught in the act,
speaker: Narrator

text: but a spirit of jealousy comes over her husband, he will be jealous of his wife when she has made herself unclean. Or if he becomes jealous of his wife when she has done nothing to make herself unclean,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the man must bring his wife to the religious leader. He must bring one-tenth part of a basket of barley as the gift needed for her. He must not pour oil on it. He must not put special perfume on it. For it is a grain gift of jealousy. It is a grain gift to make the sin remembered.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then the religious leader will bring her near and have her stand before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The religious leader will take holy water in a clay pot. He will take some of the dust on the floor of the meeting tent and put it into the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the religious leader will have the woman stand before the Lord and let the hair of the woman’s head hang loose. He will put the grain gift of remembering into her hands. It is the grain gift of jealousy. In the religious leader’s hand will be the bitter water that can bring a curse to the woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the religious leader will have her make a promise. He will say to the woman, “If no man has lain with you and if you have not turned away into sin, while under the power of your husband, this bitter water that brings punishment will not hurt you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you have turned away, while under the power of your husband, and have made yourself unclean by having another man who is not your husband,”
speaker: Narrator

text: then the religious leader will have the woman make a promise so she will be punished if she has sinned. He will say to the woman, “May the Lord make you a curse among your people. May the Lord make your leg waste away and your stomach grow bigger.
speaker: Narrator

text: This water that brings a curse will go into your stomach and make it grow bigger and your leg to waste away.” And the woman will say, “Let it be so. Let it be so.”
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then the religious leader will write these curses in a book. And he will wash them off into the bitter water.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will make the woman drink the bitter water that brings a curse. The water that brings a curse will go into her and give her pain.
speaker: Narrator

text: The religious leader will take the grain gift of jealousy from the woman’s hand. He will wave the grain gift before the Lord and bring it to the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The religious leader will fill his hand with the grain gift, as the part to be remembered. And he will burn it on the altar. Then he will make the woman drink the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she has not been faithful to her husband, the water that brings a curse will go into her and give her pain. Her stomach will get larger and her leg will become as dead. A curse will come upon the woman among her people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the woman has not sinned and is clean, she will be free and able to have children.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘This is the law of jealousy. If a wife who is under the power of her husband turns away and makes herself unclean,
speaker: Narrator

text: and a spirit of jealousy comes upon a man, making him jealous of his wife, then he must make the woman stand before the Lord. And the religious leader will do to her all the rules of this Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: The husband will be free from guilt. But the woman will carry her guilt.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘A man or woman may make a special promise, the promise of a Nazirite, to set himself apart to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he must keep away from wine and strong drink. He will drink no sour wine, made from wine or strong drink. He will not drink any grape drink. And he will not eat new or dried grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the days he is set apart, he must not eat anything made from the grape-field, not even the seeds or the skins.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘No hair of his head will be cut, all the days of his promise to be set apart. He must be holy until the time is finished for which he set himself apart to the Lord. He will let the hair on his head grow long.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘All the days he is set apart to the Lord, he must not go near a dead person.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not allow himself to be made unclean when his father, mother, brother or sister die. For he has made a promise to be set apart to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is holy to the Lord all the days he is set apart.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘But if a man dies next to him, making his hair unclean which had been set apart to the Lord, then he must cut all the hair from his head on the day he is made clean. He will cut it off on the seventh day.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day he must bring two turtle-doves or two young pigeons to the religious leader, to the door of the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: The religious leader will give one for a sin gift and the other for a burnt gift. He will pay for his sin because of the dead person. And he will make his head holy that same day.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will set apart to the Lord his days as a Nazirite. And he will bring a year old male lamb for a guilt gift. But the past days will be a loss, because he had become unclean during the time he was set apart.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘This is the Law of the Nazirite when the time he is set apart is finished. He must bring the gift to the door of the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will give his gift to the Lord. It will be a perfect male lamb a year old for a burnt gift, one perfect female lamb a year old for a sin gift, and one perfect ram for a peace gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he will give a basket of bread made of fine flour mixed with oil, made without yeast. He will give hard bread spread with oil and made without yeast. With them he will give their grain gift and drink gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the religious leader will give all these to the Lord and his sin gift and his burnt gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will also give the ram for peace gifts to the Lord, together with the basket of bread made without yeast. Then the religious leader will give its grain gift and drink gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then at the door of the meeting tent the Nazirite will cut off the hair that has been set apart for holy use. He is to take the hair and put it in the fire under the peace gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text: The religious leader will take the shoulder of the ram when it has been boiled and a loaf of bread and a piece of hard bread, both made without yeast and put them in the hands of the Nazirite. This is done after he has cut off the hair that has been set apart.
speaker: Narrator

text: The religious leader will wave them for a wave gift before the Lord. They are holy and belong to the religious leader, together with the breast given as a wave gift and the thigh given by lifting it up. After that the Nazirite may drink wine.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the Law of the Nazirite who makes a promise to give to the Lord what he promised as a Nazirite, and whatever else he is able to give. He must do what he has promised by the Law of being set apart as a Nazirite.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to Aaron and his sons, ‘This is the way you should bring good to the people of Israel. Say to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: “May the Lord bring good to you and keep you.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord make His face shine upon you, and be kind to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord show favor toward you, and give you peace.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: So they will put My name upon the people of Israel, and I will bring good to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses finished putting up the meeting tent. On that day he put oil on it and made it holy, with the things inside, the altar and all its objects. He put oil on them and made them holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the leaders of Israel, the heads of their fathers’ houses, brought their gifts. They were the leaders of the families, the heads of those who were numbered.
speaker: Narrator

text: As gifts to the Lord they brought six covered wagons and twelve bulls, a wagon for every two of the leaders and a bull for each one. Then they gave them in front of the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Receive these things from them, that they may be used in the work of the meeting tent. Give them to the Levites, to each man for the work he does.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses took the wagons and the bulls, and gave them to the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave two wagons and four bulls to the sons of Gershon, for the work they were doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave four wagons and eight bulls to the sons of Merari, for the work they were doing under the leading of Ithamar the son of Aaron the religious leader.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses did not give any to the sons of Kohath. They had the duty of taking care of the holy objects which had to be carried on their shoulders.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leaders gave gifts to set apart the altar on the day the oil was poured on it. They gave their gifts in front of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Let one leader each day give the gifts to set apart the altar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who gave his gift on the first day was Nahshon the son of Amminadab, of the family of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: His gift was one silver dish that weighed as much as 130 pieces of silver, and one silver dish that weighed as much as seventy pieces of silver. They were weighed by the weight of silver agreed upon for the meeting tent. Both of them were full of fine flour mixed with oil for a grain gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he gave one gold dish weighing as much as ten pieces of silver, full of special perfume.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave one bull, one ram, and one male lamb one year old, for a burnt gift in worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave one male goat for a sin gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the peace gifts he gave two bulls, five rams, five male goats, and five male lambs one year old. This was the gift given by Nahshon the son of Amminadab.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the second day Nethanel the son of Zuar, leader of Issachar, gave a gift in worship.
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: This was the gift to set apart the altar on the day the oil was poured on it. The leaders of Israel gave twelve silver dishes, twelve deep dishes made of silver, and twelve gold dishes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each silver dish weighed as much as 130 pieces of silver. Each deep dish weighed as much as seventy pieces of silver. All the silver of the dishes weighed as much as 2,400 pieces of silver. They were weighed by the weight of silver agreed upon for the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twelve gold dishes full of special perfume each weighed as much as ten pieces of silver. They were weighed by the weight of silver agreed upon for the meeting tent. All the gold of the dishes weighed as much as 120 pieces of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the animals given for the burnt gift were twelve bulls, twelve rams, and twelve male lambs one year old with their grain gifts. Twelve male goats were given for a sin gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the animals given for the peace gifts were twenty-four bulls, sixty rams, sixty male goats, and sixty male lambs one year old. This was the gift to set apart the altar after the oil was poured on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses went into the meeting tent to speak with the Lord. And he heard the voice speaking to him from above the mercy-seat that was on the special box with the Law, between the two cherubim. So the Lord spoke to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to Aaron, ‘When you put the seven lamps on the lamp-stand, they should give light in front of the lamp-stand.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Aaron did so. He put the lamps so they would give light in front of the lamp-stand, as the Lord had told Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now this is the way the lamp-stand was made. It was made of beaten gold from the base to its flowers. He made the lamp-stand the way the Lord had shown Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the Levites from among the people of Israel, and make them clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: To make them clean, put holy water on them that takes away sin. Let them cut all the hair from their body, and wash their clothes, and they shall be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then let them take a young bull and its grain gift of fine flour mixed with oil. Take another young bull for a sin gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring the Levites in front of the meeting tent and gather together all the people of Israel also.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring the Levites before the Lord and the people of Israel will lay their hands on the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron will give the Levites to the Lord as a wave gift from the people of Israel so they will be able to do the work of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites will lay their hands on the heads of the bulls. They will give one for a sin gift and the other for a burnt gift to the Lord, to pay for the sins of the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then have the Levites stand in front of Aaron and his sons, to give them as a wave gift to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So you will divide the Levites from the people of Israel. And the Levites will be Mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that the Levites may go in to work in the meeting tent. But you must make them clean and give them as a wave gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they are all given to Me from among the people of Israel. I have taken them for Myself instead of every first child to be born, the first-born of all the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every first-born among the people of Israel is Mine, both of man and animal. I set them apart for Myself on the day that I killed all the first-born in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have taken the Levites instead of every first-born among the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I have given the Levites as a gift to Aaron and his sons from among the people of Israel. They will do the work of the people of Israel at the meeting tent. By this they take away the sins of the people of Israel. So no trouble will come upon the people of Israel if they come near the meeting tent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron and all the people of Israel did this to the Levites. The people of Israel did to them all the things the Lord had told Moses about the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites made themselves pure, putting away their sin. And they washed their clothes. Aaron gave them as a wave gift before the Lord. He did what had to be done to pay for their sin so they would be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that the Levites went in to do their work in the meeting tent in front of Aaron and his sons. So they did to the Levites just what the Lord had told Moses to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the rule for the Levites. Those who are twenty-five years old and older will go in to do the work of the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they are fifty years old they will stop these duties and not work any more.
speaker: Narrator

text: They may help their brothers in the meeting tent to do what needs to be done but they themselves must not do the work. These are the rules for the Levites when giving them their duties.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses in the Sinai desert, in the first month of the second year after they had come out of the land of Egypt. The Lord said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let the people of Israel keep the Passover at the time given for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep it at its given time, in the evening of the fourteenth day of this month. Keep it by obeying all its Laws.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses told the people of Israel to keep the Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they kept the Passover in the evening of the fourteenth day of the first month, in the Sinai desert. The people of Israel did all that the Lord had told Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there were some men who were unclean because they had touched a dead person. So they could not keep the Passover on that day. They came to Moses and Aaron that day
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to Moses, “We are unclean because we touched a dead person. But why are we kept from giving the Lord’s gift at its given time among the people of Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to them, “Wait, and I will listen to what the Lord will tell me to do with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘If anyone of you or your children touch a dead person and become unclean, or if you are traveling far away, even so, he may still keep the Passover to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will keep it in the evening of the fourteenth day of the second month. They will eat it with bread without yeast and with bitter tasting plants.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must not leave any of it until morning. And they must not break a bone of the lamb. They must obey all of the Law of the Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if a man is clean and is not away traveling, yet does not keep the Passover, he must be cut off from his people. For he did not give the Lord’s gift at the time he was to do so. That man will be guilty of his sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a stranger staying with you wants to keep the Passover to the Lord and obey the Law of the Passover, he may do so. You will have one law, both for the stranger and for the one who was born in the land.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day that the meeting tent was set up, the cloud covered the meeting tent, the tent of the law. In the evening it was over the meeting tent. It looked like fire until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was like this always. The cloud would cover it during the day. What looked like fire would cover it during the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the cloud was lifted from over the meeting tent, the people of Israel would move on. Where the cloud rested, there the people of Israel would set up their tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel would move on as the Lord told them. And they would set up their tents as the Lord told them. They stayed in one place as long as the cloud rested over the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even when the cloud rested over the meeting tent for many days, the people of Israel would obey the Lord and not leave.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sometimes the cloud stayed a few days over the meeting tent. But they obeyed the Lord and stayed in that place. Then they would leave when the Lord told them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sometimes the cloud stayed from evening until morning. When the cloud lifted in the morning, they would leave. If the cloud stayed during the day and the night, when it was lifted, they would leave that place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even when the cloud stayed over the meeting tent for two days, or a month, or a year the people of Israel would stay in that place and not leave. They would leave when it was lifted.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set up their tents as the Lord told them. And they moved on as the Lord told them. They obeyed what the Lord had told them to do through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make two silver horns of beaten silver. Use them for calling the people together and for having the people move on.
speaker: Narrator

text: When both horns sound, all the people will gather in front of you at the door of the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: If only one horn sounds, then the leaders, the heads of the families of Israel, will gather in front of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you blow the horn to tell of danger, the people whose tents are on the east side will leave.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you blow the horn to tell of danger a second time, the people whose tents are on the south side will leave. A horn telling of danger will be blown when they are to move on.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the people are to be gathered together, you will blow the horn without the sound of danger.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron’s sons, the religious leaders, will blow the horns. This will be a Law for all your people forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you go to war in your land against those who fight you, then sound the horns to tell of war. That way you will be remembered before the Lord your God, and be saved from those who hate you.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the days you are glad and at the time of your special suppers and on the first days of your months, blow the horns. Blow the horns over your burnt gifts and over your peace gifts. Then you will be remembered before your God. I am the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the twentieth day of the second month in the second year, the cloud was lifted from over the meeting tent of the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel moved on from the Desert of Sinai. Then the cloud came down and rested in the desert of Paran.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they moved for the first time as the Lord had told them through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The flag of the people of Judah left first, by their armies. Amminadab’s son Nahshon was the head of their army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zuar’s son Nethanel was the head of the men of Issachar.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Helon’s son Eliab was the head of the men of Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the meeting tent was taken down, the sons of Gershon and Merari left carrying it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next the flag of the people of Reuben left, by their armies. Shedeur’s son Elizur was the head over this army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zurishaddai’s son Shelumiel was the head of the men of Simeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Deuel’s son Eliasaph was the head of the men of Gad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Kohathites left, carrying the holy objects. The meeting tent was set up before they came to the next place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next the flag of the people of Ephraim left, by their armies. Ammihud’s son Elishama was the head over this army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pedahzur’s son Gamaliel was the head of the men of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideoni’s son Abidan was the head of the men of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the flag of the people of Dan left, by their armies. They followed behind all the people of Israel, to watch for danger. Ammishaddai’s son Ahiezer was the head over this army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ochran’s son Pagiel was the head of the men of Asher.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Enan’s son Ahira was the head of the men of Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was how the people of Israel moved on by their armies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Hobab the son of Reuel the Midianite, Moses’ father-in-law, “We are going to the place the Lord said He will give to us. Come with us and we will do you good. For the Lord has promised good to Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Hobab said to him, “I will not come. I will go to my own land and family.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “I beg you, do not leave us. For you know where we should stay in the desert. You will be like eyes for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you go with us, we will do for you whatever good the Lord does for us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they traveled for three days from the mountain of the Lord with the special box with the Law of the Lord in front of them looking for a place for them to rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cloud of the Lord was over them during the day, when they moved on.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the special box of the Lord moved on, Moses said, “Rise up, O Lord! Let those who hate You be divided. Let those who hate You run away before You.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when it rested, he said, “Return, O Lord, to the many thousands of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the people complained about their troubles in the hearing of the Lord. When the Lord heard it, His anger burned. The fire of the Lord burned among them, and destroyed some around the outer parts of the tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people cried to Moses and he prayed to the Lord, and the fire went out.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the name of that place was called Taberah, because the fire of the Lord burned among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The mixed group of people among them had strong desires. The people of Israel cried again and said, “Who will give us meat to eat?
speaker: Narrator

text: We remember all the fish we could eat free in Egypt, and all the fruit and vegetables and spices.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now our strength is gone. There is nothing at all to look at except this bread from heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the bread from heaven was like coriander seed, and it looked like bdellium.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people would go and gather it and beat it between stones. They boiled it in a pot or made bread with it. It tasted like bread made with oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the grass became wet around the tents at night, the bread from heaven would fall.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses heard all the people crying in every family, each man at the door of his tent. The Lord became very angry with them and Moses was not pleased.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses said to the Lord, “Why have You been so hard on Your servant? Why have I not found favor in Your eyes, that You have laid the troubles of all these people on me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Did I give birth to all these people? Did I bring them out, that You should say to me, ‘Carry them close to your heart as a nurse carries a nursing baby, to the land You promised their fathers’?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where am I to get meat to give to all these people? They cry in front of me, saying, ‘Give us meat so we may eat!’
speaker: Narrator

text: I am not able to carry all these people alone. The load is too heavy for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So if You are going to act this way toward me, I beg You to kill me now, if I have found favor in Your eyes. Do not let me see how bad off I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Gather for Me seventy men from the leaders of Israel, whom you know to be the leaders of the people, the men who rule over them. Bring them to the meeting tent and let them stand there with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will come down and speak with you there. I will take of the Spirit Who is upon you, and will put Him upon them. Then they will carry the troubles of the people with you so you will not carry them all alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to the people, ‘Make yourselves holy for tomorrow, and you will eat meat. The Lord heard you when you cried and said, “If only someone would give us meat to eat! For it was well with us in Egypt.” So the Lord will give you meat and you will eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will not eat it for only one day, or two days, or five days, or ten days, or twenty days.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you will eat it a whole month, until it comes out of your nose and you hate it, because you have turned away from the Lord Who is among you. You have cried before Him, saying, “Why did we ever leave Egypt?”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “The people whom I am among are 600,000 on foot. And You have said, ‘I will give them meat so they may eat for a whole month.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Will enough flocks and cattle be killed to feed them? Or will enough fish be gathered from the sea to feed them?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Is there an end to the Lord’s power? Now you will see if My Word will come true for you or not.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went out and told the people the words of the Lord. And he gathered seventy men from the leaders of the people, and had them stand around the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord came down in the cloud and spoke to him. He took of the Spirit Who was upon him and put Him upon the seventy leaders. When the Spirit rested upon them, they spoke the word of the Lord. But they did not do it again.
speaker: Narrator

text: But two men had stayed among the tents. Their names were Eldad and Medad, and the Spirit rested upon them. They were among those who had been chosen, but had not gone out to the meeting tent. So they spoke the word of the Lord among the tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: A young man ran and told Moses, “Eldad and Medad are speaking the word of the Lord among the tents.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua the son of Nun, the helper of Moses since he was young, said, “Moses, my lord, do not let them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said to him, “Are you jealous for my good? If only all the Lord’s people would speak for God, that the Lord would put His Spirit upon them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and the leaders of Israel returned to the tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a wind went out from the Lord. It brought quail from the sea, and let them fall beside the place where the tents were set up. They fell all around the tents, about as far on each side as it takes to travel in a day. They lay on the ground as deep as two cubits.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people worked all day and all night and all the next day gathering the quail. He who gathered the least gathered enough to fill 110 baskets. And they spread them out for themselves all around the tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: While the meat was still between their teeth and not yet eaten, the Lord became angry with the people. The Lord sent a bad sickness upon the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the name of that place was called Kibroth-hattaavah. Because there they buried the people who had wanted meat to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people left Kibroth-hattaavah and went to Hazeroth. And they stayed at Hazeroth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses because of his Cushite wife, for he had married a Cushite woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “Is it true that the Lord has spoken only through Moses? Has He not spoken through us also?” And the Lord heard it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Moses was a man with no pride, more so than any man on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: At once the Lord said to Moses and Aaron and Miriam, “You three come out to the meeting tent.” So the three of them came out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord came down in a cloud and stood at the door of the meeting tent, and called Aaron and Miriam. When both of them had come near,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord said, “Now listen to Me. If there is a man who speaks for God among you, I the Lord will make Myself known to him in a special dream. I will speak with him in a dream.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not so, with My servant Moses. He is faithful in all My house.
speaker: Narrator

text: With him I speak face to face in ways he understands, and not in ways he does not understand. And he sees what the Lord is like. Why then were you not afraid to speak against My servant Moses?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was angry with them, and He left.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the cloud lifted from over the meeting tent, Miriam had a very bad skin disease. She was as white as snow. Aaron turned toward Miriam and saw that she had a bad skin disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron said to Moses, “O, my lord, I beg you. Do not punish us because we have been foolish and have sinned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let her not be like one who is dead, whose flesh is half eaten away when he is born!”‘
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses cried to the Lord, saying, “O God, heal her, I pray!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Moses, “If her father had only spit in her face, would she not carry her shame for seven days? Let her be shut up for seven days away from the tents. After that, she may be brought in again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Miriam was shut up away from the tents for seven days. And the people did not travel on until Miriam was brought in again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people moved from Hazeroth after that. And they set up their tents in the desert of Paran.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Send men to spy out the land of Canaan which I am going to give to the people of Israel. Send a man from each of their fathers’ families, every one a leader among them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses sent them from the desert of Paran, as the Lord had told him. All of the men were heads of the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were their names. There was Shammua the son of Zaccur from the family of Reuben,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shaphat the son of Hori from the family of Simeon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Caleb the son of Jephunneh from the family of Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Igal the son of Joseph from the family of Issachar.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was Hoshea the son of Nun from the family of Ephraim,
speaker: Narrator

text: Palti the son of Raphu from the family of Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: Gaddiel the son of Sodi from the family of Zebulun,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Gaddi the son of Susi from the family of Joseph, from the family of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was Ammiel the son of Gemalli from the family of Dan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Sethur the son of Michael from the family of Asher,
speaker: Narrator

text: Nahbi the son of Vophsi from the family of Naphtali,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Geuel the son of Machi from the family of Gad.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the men whom Moses sent to spy out the land. But Moses called Hoshea the son of Nun, Joshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent them to spy out the land of Canaan. He said to them, “Go up there into the Negev. Then go up into the hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: See what the land is like. See if the people who live in it are strong or weak, and if they are few or many.
speaker: Narrator

text: Find out if the land they live in is good or bad. See if the cities they live in are open or if they have walls.
speaker: Narrator

text: Find out if the land is rich or poor, and if there are trees in it or not. Then try to get some of the fruit of the land.” Now this was the gathering time of the first grown grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went up and spied out the land from the Desert of Zin as far as Rehob, at Lebo-hamath.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had gone up into the Negev, they came to Hebron. Anak’s sons Ahiman, Sheshai and Talmai were there. (Hebron was built seven years before Zoan in Egypt.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they came to the valley of Eshcol. They cut down a branch from there with some grapes on it. And they carried it on a long piece of wood between two men, with some pomegranates and figs.
speaker: Narrator

text: That place was called the valley of Eshcol, because of much fruit the men of Israel cut down from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They returned from looking over the land after forty days.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they came to Moses and Aaron and to all the people of Israel in the desert of Paran, at Kadesh. They brought news to them and to all the people, and showed them the fruit of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told Moses, “We went to the land where you sent us. It does flow with milk and honey. This is its fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people who live in the land are strong. The cities have walls and are very large. And we saw the children of Anak there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amalek is living in the land of the Negev. The Hittites and Jebusites and Amorites are living in the hill country. And the Canaanites are living by the sea and by the side of the Jordan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Caleb told the people in front of Moses to be quiet. And he said, “Let us go up at once and take the land. For we are well able to take it in battle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the men who had gone up with him said, “We are not able to go against the people. They are too strong for us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they brought the people of Israel bad news about the land they had spied out, saying, “The land we have gone to spy out is a land that destroys those who go there to live. All the people we saw in it are very large.
speaker: Narrator

text: We saw the Nephilim there. (The sons of Anak are part of the Nephilim.) We looked like grasshoppers in our own eyes, and we looked the same to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people cried out with a loud voice, and they cried that night.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people of Israel complained against Moses and Aaron, and said to them, “If only we had died in the land of Egypt! Or if only we had died in this desert!
speaker: Narrator

text: Why is the Lord bringing us into this land to be killed by the sword? Our wives and our little ones will be taken away. Would it not be better for us to return to Egypt?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they said to one another, “Let us choose a leader and return to Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron fell on their faces in front of all the gathering of the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joshua the son of Nun and Caleb the son of Jephunneh tore their clothes. They were among those who had spied out the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to all the people of Israel, “The land we passed through to spy out is a very good land.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the Lord is pleased with us, then He will bring us into this land and give it to us. It is a land which flows with milk and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only do not go against the Lord. And do not be afraid of the people of the land. For they will be our food. They have no way to keep safe, and the Lord is with us. Do not be afraid of them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But all the people said to throw stones at Joshua and Caleb. Then the shining-greatness of the Lord was seen in the meeting tent by all the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “How long will this people turn away from Me? How long will they not believe in Me, even after all the great works I have done among them?
speaker: Narrator

text: I will punish them with disease, and will not give them the land. And I will make you into a nation greater and stronger than they.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said to the Lord, “Then the Egyptians will hear of it. For You brought this people here by Your strength from among them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And they will tell the people who live in this land. They have heard
that You, O Lord, are with these people and that You, O Lord, are seen face to face as Your cloud is over them. You go before them in a cloud during the day, and in fire during the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if You kill these people as one man, the nations who have heard how great You are will say,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The Lord was not able to bring these people into the land He promised to give them. So He has killed them in the desert.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, I pray, let the power of the Lord be great as You have promised, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The Lord is slow to anger and filled with loving-kindness, forgiving sin and wrong-doing. But He will not let the guilty go without being punished. He brings the sin of fathers down upon the children, even the great-grandchildren.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I pray that You will forgive the sin of this people by the greatness of Your loving-kindness. Forgive them as You have forgiven them from Egypt until now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said, “I have forgiven them as you asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: But for sure, as I live, all the earth will be filled with the shining-greatness of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men who have seen My greatness and My wonderful works which I did in Egypt and in the desert but have put Me to the test these ten times and have not listened to My voice, for sure, they
speaker: Narrator

text: will not see the land I promised to their fathers. None of those who have turned away from Me will see it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But My servant Caleb has had a different spirit and has followed Me in every way. I will bring him into the land where he went, and his children will take it for themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Amalekites and the Canaanites live in the valleys. So turn tomorrow and move on to the desert by the way of the Red Sea.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “How long will these sinful people speak against Me? I have heard the people of Israel complaining against Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to them, ‘As I live, what you have said in My hearing I will do to you,’ says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Your dead bodies will fall in this desert, all of you who were numbered from twenty years old and older, who have spoken against Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For sure, not one will go into the land where I promised to have you live, except Caleb the son of Jephunneh and Joshua the son of Nun.
speaker: Narrator

text: You said that your children would be taken and killed. But I will bring them in, and they will know the land you have turned away from.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for you, your dead bodies will fall in this desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your children will be shepherds in the desert for forty years. They will suffer because you were not faithful, until your dead bodies lie in the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: You spied out the land for forty days. For each day you will carry your guilt a year, forty years. And you will know that I am against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I the Lord have spoken. For sure I will do this to all these sinful people who are gathered together against Me. They will be destroyed in this desert. And there they will die.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses had sent men to spy out the land. They returned and made all the people complain against him by bringing bad news about the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: These men who brought the very bad news about the land died of a disease before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joshua the son of Nun and Caleb the son of Jephunneh stayed alive, of those men who went to spy out the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses told these words to all the people of Israel, the people were filled with much sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: They got up early in the morning and went up to the top of the hill country, saying, “Here we are. It is true we have sinned. But we will go up to the place which the Lord has promised.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “Why now do you sin against the Word of the Lord? It will not get you what you want.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not go up, or you will be killed by those who fight against you. For the Lord is not with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Amalekites and the Canaanites will be there in front of you, and you will be killed by the sword. Because you have turned away from following the Lord, the Lord will not be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they would not listen and went up to the top of the hill country. The special box with the Law of the Lord, and Moses, did not leave the tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Amalekites and the Canaanites who lived in that hill country came down and went against them and beat them down as far as Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘When you go into the land where you are to live, which I am giving you,
speaker: Narrator

text: then give a gift in worship by fire to the Lord. Give a gift from the herd or the flock, a burnt gift, or a gift to keep a special promise, or a free-will gift, or one during special suppers. This will be to make a pleasing smell to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who brings his gift will bring to the Lord a grain gift of one-tenth part of a basket of fine flour mixed with one-fourth part of a large jar of oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: And make ready one-fourth part of a large jar of wine to pour over the burnt gift or for each lamb given on the altar in worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or for a ram, make ready a grain gift of two-tenths part of a basket of fine flour mixed with one-third part of a large jar of oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then make one-third part of a large jar of wine for the drink gift, a pleasing smell to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may make ready a bull for a burnt gift or give an animal on the altar in worship, to keep a special promise, or give peace gifts to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the bull bring a grain gift of three-tenths part of a basket of fine flour mixed with half a large jar of oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring for the drink gift half a large jar of wine, as a gift by fire, a pleasing smell to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘It must be done this way for each bull, or for each ram, or for each of the male lambs or young goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever number you make ready, you must do for everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: All who are born in the land must do these things in this way by giving a gift by fire, a pleasing smell to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: A stranger staying with you, or a man living among your people, may want to give a gift by fire, a pleasing smell to the Lord. Then he must do just as you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be one Law for you and for the stranger who stays with you. It will be a Law forever for all your children-to-come. As you are, so will the stranger be before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: One Law will be for you and for the stranger who stays with you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘When you come into the land where I bring you
speaker: Narrator

text: and when you eat of the food of the land, you must lift up a gift in worship to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give a loaf of bread as a gift from the first of your grain. Give it as the gift of the grain-floor.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the first of your grain you and all your children-to-come must give a gift to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Without knowing it you might not obey all these Laws which the Lord has spoken to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: even all that the Lord has told you to do through Moses, from the day when the Lord told you and through all your children-to-come.
speaker: Narrator

text: If this is done without the people knowing it, then all the people must give one bull for a burnt gift. It will be a pleasing smell to the Lord. It must be brought with its grain gift and its drink gift, by the Law, and with one male goat for a sin gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the religious leader will pay for the sins of all the people of Israel, and they will be forgiven. Because it was a mistake, they brought their gift, a gift by fire to the Lord, and their sin gift to the Lord, for their mistake.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the people of Israel and the stranger who stays among them will be forgiven. For it happened to all the people by mistake.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘If one person sins without knowing it, he must bring a one year old female goat for a sin gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the religious leader before the Lord will pay for the sin of the person who sins without knowing it. He will pay for his sin so he may be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will have one Law for him who does anything without knowing it, for him who is one of the people of Israel and for the stranger who lives among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if a person born in the land or a stranger does anything wrong and means to do it, he is speaking against the Lord. That person must be cut off from among his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because he has hated the Word of the Lord and has broken His Law, that person must be cut off for sure. His guilt will be on him.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: While the people of Israel were in the desert, they found a man gathering wood on the Day of Rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who found him gathering wood brought him to Moses and Aaron, and to all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They put him in chains, because they did not know what should be done to him for gathering wood on the Day of Rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses: “The man must be put to death. All the people must kill him with stones away from the tents.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the people took him away from the tents and killed him with stones, just as the Lord had told Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the people of Israel. Tell them that they and all their children-to-come are to make tassels for themselves on the corners of their clothing. And they are to put a blue rope on the tassel of each corner.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be a tassel for you to look at and remember all the Laws of the Lord, and to do them. Do not follow your own heart and your own eyes, as you did when you acted like a woman selling the use of her body.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be so that you may remember to obey all My Laws, and be holy to your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the Lord your God Who brought you out from the land of Egypt to be your God. I am the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Korah the son of Izhar, the son of Kohath, the son of Levi, with Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, and On the son of Peleth, sons of Reuben, caused trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came in front of Moses, together with some of the sons of Israel. They had chosen 250 leaders of the people of Israel, well-known men.
speaker: Narrator

text: They all gathered together against Moses and Aaron, and said to them, “You have gone too far! For all the people are holy, every one of them, and the Lord is among them. So why do you honor yourselves more than the people of the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses heard this, he bowed to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to Korah and all who were with him, “Tomorrow morning the Lord will show who is His, and who is holy. He will have him come near to Him. He will bring near to Himself the one whom He will choose.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this, Korah and all who are with you. Take pots for burning special perfume.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put fire in them, and put special perfume upon them before the Lord tomorrow. The man whom the Lord chooses will be the one who is holy. You have gone too far, you sons of Levi!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Korah, “Hear now, you sons of Levi.
