speaker: Narrator

text: Is it not enough for you that the God of Israel has set you apart from the rest of the people of Israel? He has brought you near to Himself. He has you do the work around the meeting tent of the Lord. And He has you stand in front of the people to care for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has brought you near to Him, Korah, and all your brothers who are the sons of Levi, with you. Would you try to be the religious leaders also?
speaker: Narrator

text: So you and all who are with you are gathered together against the Lord. But as for Aaron, who is he that you complain against him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses sent to call Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab. But they said, “We will not come up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it not enough that you have brought us up out of a land flowing with milk and honey to have us die in the desert? Must you make yourself a ruler over us also?
speaker: Narrator

text: More than this, you have not brought us into a land flowing with milk and honey. You have not given us any land with fields and grape vines. Would you put out the eyes of these men? We will not come up!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses became very angry. He said to the Lord, “Do not respect their gift! I have not taken one donkey from them. And I have not hurt one of them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Korah, “You and all who are with you be before the Lord tomorrow, you and they, and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of you take his fire pot and put special perfume on it. And each of you bring his fire pot before the Lord, 250 fire pots. Let both you and Aaron bring his fire pot also.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So each man took his fire pot and put fire in it and put special perfume on it. And they stood at the door of the meeting tent with Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Korah gathered together all the people against them at the door of the meeting tent. And the shining-greatness of the Lord was seen by all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go away from these people, so I may destroy them at once.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they fell on their faces, and said, “O God, the God of the spirits of all flesh, when one man sins, will You be angry with all the people?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the people, ‘Get away from the tents of Korah, Dathan and Abiram.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses got up and went to Dathan and Abiram, with the leaders of Israel following him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to the people, “Go away now from the tents of these sinful men. Touch nothing that belongs to them, or you will be destroyed because of all their sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went away from the tents of Korah, Dathan and Abiram. And Dathan and Abiram came out and stood at the door of their tents, with their wives, their sons, and their little ones.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “By this you will know that the Lord has sent me to do all these works. For this is not my doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: If these men die in the same way all men die, or if what happens to everyone happens to them, then the Lord has not sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord will do something new. The ground will open its mouth and take them with all that belongs to them. And they will go down alive into the place of the dead. Then you will understand that these men have turned against the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he stopped speaking, the ground under them opened up.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth opened its mouth and took them and all those of their house, and all Korah’s men and all that belonged to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They and all that belonged to them went down alive to the place of the dead, and the earth closed over them. They were destroyed from among the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all Israel who were around them ran away at their cry. For they said, “The earth may take us too!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then fire came from the Lord and destroyed the 250 men who had brought the special perfume.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Eleazar the son of Aaron the religious leader to take the fire pots out of the fire. For they are holy. Then spread the burning pieces far apart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the fire pots of these men who have sinned and lost their lives be made into beaten plates to cover the altar. For they did bring them to the Lord and they are holy. They will be something special for the people of Israel to see.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Eleazar the religious leader took the brass fire pots which the men who were burned had brought. And they beat them into plates to cover the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were to make the people of Israel remember that no man who is not a religious leader and a son of Aaron should come to burn special perfume before the Lord. Or he might become like Korah and those who were with him, as the Lord said to Eleazar through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: But on the next day all the people of Israel complained against Moses and Aaron, saying, “You are the ones who have caused the death of the Lord’s people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people had gathered against Moses and Aaron, they turned toward the meeting tent. There the cloud covered it and they saw the shining-greatness of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron came to the front of the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Get away from these people, so I may destroy them at once.” Then they fell on their faces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Aaron, “Take your fire pot and put fire in it from the altar, and lay special perfume on it. Then be quick to bring it to the people and pay for their sin. For anger has gone out from the Lord. The disease has come!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron took it as Moses said, and ran to the people. The disease had already come upon them. He put on the special perfume and paid for the sin of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stood between the dead and the living, and the disease was stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: But 14,700 people died by the disease, as well as those who died because of Korah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron returned to Moses at the door of the meeting tent, for the disease had been stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the people of Israel. Get walking sticks from them, one for each father’s house. Get twelve walking sticks, from all their leaders by their fathers’ houses. Write each man’s name on his stick.
speaker: Narrator

text: Write Aaron’s name on the walking stick of Levi. For there will be one walking stick for the head of each father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then put them in the meeting tent before the Law, where I meet with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the walking stick of the man I choose will begin to grow. In this way I will stop the complaining of the people of Israel, who are complaining against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses spoke to the people of Israel. All their leaders each gave him a walking stick, one for each leader by their fathers’ houses, twelve walking sticks. And the walking stick of Aaron was among their walking sticks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses put the walking sticks before the Lord in the meeting tent of the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day Moses went into the meeting tent of the Law. And he saw that the walking stick of Aaron for the house of Levi had begun to grow buds and flowers and almonds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses brought out all the walking sticks from before the Lord to all the people of Israel. They looked, and each man took his stick.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Moses, “Put the walking stick of Aaron in front of the Law again. It will be something special to see against those who go against My Word. Then you may put an end to their complaining against Me, so they will not die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses did this. He did just as the Lord had told him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people of Israel said to Moses, “See, we are being destroyed! We are dying! We are all dying!
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who comes near, who comes near the meeting tent of the Lord, must die. Are we all to be destroyed?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Aaron, “You and your sons and those of your father’s house will carry the guilt for any sin done in the meeting tent. And you and your sons with you will carry the guilt of any sin of the religious leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring with you your brothers also, the family of Levi, the family of your father. Then they may join you and help you while you and your sons are in front of the meeting tent of the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will help you and help in doing all the work of the tent. But they must not come near the objects of the meeting tent and the altar, or both they and you will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will join you and help do all the work of the meeting tent. But no one else may come near you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must do the work of the meeting tent and the work of the altar, so there will no longer be anger on the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I Myself have taken your brothers the Levites from among the people of Israel. They are a gift to you, given to the Lord, to do the work for the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you and your sons with you will do the religious work, in all that has to do with the altar and inside the curtain. I am giving you the work of being the religious leader as a gift. Anyone else who comes near the holy objects will be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Aaron, “Now see, I am giving you all the gifts brought to Me that are not burned on the altar. I am giving them to you as a share, and to your sons as a share forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: This will be yours from the most holy gifts, kept from the fire: every gift of theirs, even every grain gift, every sin gift and every guilt gift, which they bring to Me. They will be most holy for you and your sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will eat it as the most holy gifts. Every male will eat it. It will be holy to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this is yours: their gift that is lifted up and all the wave gifts of the people of Israel. I am giving them to you and to your sons and daughters with you, as a share forever. Everyone in your house who is clean may eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I give to you all the best of the oil and all the best of the wine and of the grain, the first-fruits of what they give to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first-fruits ready to eat of all that is in their land, which they bring to the Lord, will be yours. Everyone in your house who is clean may eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything in Israel that has been set apart to the Lord will be yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every first-born of all flesh, man or animal, which they give to the Lord, will be yours. But you must pay the price and make free the first-born of man and the first-born of animals that are unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must make them free when they are one month old. The price to free them will be five large pieces of silver, the price decided upon at the meeting tent. One large piece of silver is worth twenty small pieces of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: But do not free the first-born of a bull or sheep or goat. For they are holy. You will put their blood on the altar and burn their fat as a gift by fire, a pleasing smell to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But their meat will be yours, like the breast of a wave gift and like the right thigh are yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have given to you and your sons and daughters, for a share forever, all the holy gifts which the people of Israel bring to the Lord. It is an agreement of salt forever before the Lord for you and your children with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Aaron, “You will have no share in their land. You will not own any part of land among them. I am your part and your share among the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “See, I have given a tenth part of everything in Israel to the Levites, in return for the work they do, the work of the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel must not come near the meeting tent again, or they will be guilty of sin and die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only the Levites may do the work around the meeting tent, and they will carry their sin. It will be a Law forever for all your children-to-come. And they will have no land among the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I have given to the Levites one-tenth part of what the people of Israel give to the Lord. This is why I have said of them, ‘They will have no land among the people of Israel.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to the Levites, ‘When you take from the people of Israel the tenth which I have given you from them for your share, then give a gift from it to the Lord. Give one-tenth part of the tenth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And your gift will be to you as if it were the grain from the grain-floor or all the wine from the crushed grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you must give a gift to the Lord from the tenth of what you receive from the people of Israel. And from it you must give the Lord’s gift to Aaron the religious leader.
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of all the gifts to you, you must give every gift that should go to the Lord, from all the best of them. Give the holy part from them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “And say to them, ‘When you have given the best part of it, the rest of it will be to you as if it were the grain from the grain-floor and the wine from the crushed grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text: You and those of your houses may eat it in any place. For it is your pay for your work in the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will not be guilty because of it, when you have given the best of it. But do not make unclean the holy gifts of the people of Israel, or you will die.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the Law which the Lord has told you. Tell the people of Israel to bring you a young red cow that is perfect, one that has never pulled a load.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will give it to Eleazar the religious leader. It will be brought away from the tents and killed in front of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next Eleazar the religious leader will take some of its blood with his finger, and put some of it toward the front of the meeting tent seven times.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eleazar will watch the young cow being burned. Its skin, its flesh, its blood and its waste will be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: The religious leader will take cedar wood and hyssop and red cloth, and put it on the burning cow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the religious leader will wash his clothes and wash his body in water. After this the religious leader may come among the tents, but he will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who burns it will also wash his clothes and wash his body in water. And he will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a man who is clean will gather up the ashes of the young cow and put them in a clean place away from the tents. They will be kept for the people of Israel to mix with the water used to make things clean, to take away sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who gathers the ashes of the young cow must wash his clothes. He will be unclean until evening. This will be a Law forever to the people of Israel and to the stranger who lives among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The one who touches the dead body of any person will be unclean for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must clean himself with the water on the third day and on the seventh day. Then he will be clean. But if he does not clean himself on the third day and on the seventh day, he will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever touches the body of any man who has died, and does not make himself clean, makes the meeting tent of the Lord unclean. That person must be cut off from Israel. Because the water for cleaning was not put upon him, he will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the Law when a man dies in a tent. Everyone who comes into the tent and everyone who is in the tent will be unclean for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: And every open pot that has no cover on it will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone in an open field who touches one who has been killed with a sword, or who has died, or who touches a bone of a man, or a grave will be unclean for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The person who is unclean must take some of the ashes from the burning of the sin gift. Clean water must be added to them in a pot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a clean person must take hyssop and put it in the water, and put it on the tent and on all the objects within the tent. He must put it on the persons who were there, and on the one who touched the bone or the man who was killed or the dead person or the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text: The clean person must put the water on whoever is unclean, on the third day and on the seventh day. He will make him clean on the seventh day. He will wash his clothes and wash himself in water, and will be clean at evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the man who is unclean and does not make himself clean, will no longer be one of God’s people. Because he has made unclean the holy place of the Lord. The water for cleaning has not been put on him. He is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be a Law forever for them. He who puts the water on to be made clean must wash his clothes. And he who touches the water used to be made clean will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anything that the person who is unclean touches will be unclean. And the person who touches it will be unclean until evening.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people of Israel came to the Desert of Zin in the first month. And the people stayed at Kadesh. Miriam died there and was buried.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was no water for the people, and they gathered together against Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people complained to Moses, saying, “If only we had died when our brothers died before the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text: Why have you brought the Lord’s people into this desert, for us and our animals to die here?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why have you made us come up from Egypt, to bring us into this bad place? It is not a place of grain, or figs, or vines, or pomegranates. And there is no water to drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron went from the people to the door of the meeting tent, and bowed to the ground. They saw the shining-greatness of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the special stick. You and your brother Aaron gather the people together. Speak to the rock in front of them and it will give its water. So you will bring water out of the rock for them. Let the people and their animals drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses took the special stick from before the Lord, just as He had told him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron gathered the people in front of the rock. And he said to them, “Listen now, you people who go against the Lord. Should we bring water for you out of this rock?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses lifted up his hand and hit the rock twice with his stick, and more than enough water came out. The people and their animals drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Because you have not believed Me and honored Me as holy in the eyes of the people of Israel, you will not bring these people into the land I have given them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the waters of Meribah because the people of Israel complained against the Lord, and He proved Himself holy among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent men from Kadesh to the king of Edom, saying, “This is what your brother Israel has said: ‘You know all the troubles we have had.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our fathers went down to Egypt, and we lived in Egypt a long time. The Egyptians were bad in the way they acted toward us.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we cried out to the Lord. He heard our voice and sent an angel and brought us out from Egypt. Now look, we are at Kadesh, a town at the side of your country.
speaker: Narrator

text: We ask you to let us pass through your land. We will not pass through field or vines. We will not even drink water from a well. We will go on the king’s road and will not turn to the right or left, until we pass through your country.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Edom said to him, “You must not pass through, or I will come out with the sword against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel said to him, “We will go up by the straight road. If I and my animals do drink any of your water, then I will pay for it. Let me only pass through on my feet, nothing else.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Edom said, “You must not pass through.” And Edom came out against him with many men and much strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: Edom would not let Israel pass through his country. So Israel turned away from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they traveled from Kadesh, all the people of Israel came to Mount Hor.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron at Mount Hor by the side of the land of Edom, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Aaron will be buried with his people. For he will not go into the land I have given to the people of Israel, because you went against what I told you to do at the waters of Meribah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take Aaron and his son Eleazar, and bring them up to Mount Hor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the clothing off Aaron and put them on his son Eleazar. Aaron will die there and be buried with his people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did just as the Lord had told him. They went up to Mount Hor before the eyes of all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Moses had taken the clothing off Aaron and put them on his son Eleazar, Aaron died there on the mountain top. Then Moses and Eleazar came down from the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the people saw that Aaron had died, all the house of Israel cried in sorrow for Aaron thirty days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Canaanite, the king of Arad, who lived in the Negev, heard that Israel was coming by the way of Atharim. He fought against Israel, and took some of them against their will.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel made a promise to the Lord, and said, “If You will give this people into my hand, I will destroy every part of their cities.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord heard the voice of Israel, and gave them the Canaanites. Then Israel destroyed all of them and their cities. So the name of the place was called Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they traveled from Mount Hor by the way of the Red Sea, to go around the land of Edom. And the people wanted to give up because of the long way.
speaker: Narrator

text: They spoke against God and Moses, saying, “Why have you brought us up out of Egypt to die in the desert? For there is no food and no water. And we hate this bad food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord sent snakes with a bite of poison among the people. They bit the people, so that many people of Israel died.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people came to Moses and said, “We have sinned, because we have spoken against the Lord and you. Pray to the Lord, that He will take away the snakes from us.” So Moses prayed for the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Make a special snake and put it up on a long piece of wood. Everyone who is bitten will live when he looks at it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses made a brass snake and put it up on the long piece of wood. If a snake bit any man, he would live when he looked at the brass snake.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel traveled on, and set up their tents in Oboth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they left Oboth and stopped at Iye-abarim, in the desert beside Moab, to the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they traveled on to Wadi Zered.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from there they traveled on and set up their tents on the other side of the Arnon. It is in the desert that goes out from the land of the Amorites. For the Arnon is the side of Moab, between Moab and the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it is said in the Book of the Wars of the Lord: “Waheb in Suphah, and the valleys of the Arnon,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the hill-side of the valleys that goes to the place of Ar, and rests on the side of Moab.”
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they went on to Beer. That is the well where the Lord said to Moses, “Gather the people together, so I may give them water.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel sang this song: “Come up, O well! Sing to it!
speaker: Narrator

text: The well, which the leaders dug, which the rulers of the people dug, with the special stick of power and with their walking sticks.” From the desert they went on to Mattanah.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Mattanah they went to Nahaliel, and from Nahaliel to Bamoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Bamoth they went to the valley in the land of Moab, at the top of Pisgah which looks down upon the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel sent men to Sihon king of the Amorites, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let me pass through your land. We will not turn aside into field or vines. We will not drink water from wells. We will go on the king’s road until we have passed through your country.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sihon would not let Israel pass through his country. He gathered all his people and went out against Israel in the desert. He came to Jahaz and fought against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel killed Sihon with the sword. They took his land from the Arnon to the Jabbok, as far as the people of Ammon. For Jazer was the side of the land of the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel took all these cities. They lived in all the cities of the Amorites, in Heshbon, and in all its towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Heshbon was the city of Sihon king of the Amorites. He had fought against the man who was once the king of Moab, and had taken all his land as far as the Arnon.
speaker: Narrator

text: So those who use wise sayings say, “Come to Heshbon! Let it be built! Let the city of Sihon be built.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a fire went out from Heshbon, fire from the city of Sihon. It burned up Ar of Moab, and the lords of the high places of the Arnon.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is bad for you, O Moab! You are destroyed, O people of Chemosh! His sons run for their lives. His daughters have been taken against their will by an Amorite king, Sihon.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we have put them down. Heshbon is destroyed as far as Dibon. We have destroyed even to Nophah, which goes to Medeba.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel lived in the land of the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses sent men to spy out Jazer in secret. And Israel took its towns and took the place of the Amorites who were there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they turned and went up by the way of Bashan. Og the king of Bashan went out with all his people to battle at Edrei.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Moses, “Do not be afraid of him. For I have given him into your hand, with all his people and his land. Do to him as you did to Sihon king of the Amorites who lived at Heshbon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people of Israel killed Og and his sons and all his people, until there was not one left alive. And they took his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people of Israel traveled on and set up their tents in the plains of Moab on the other side of the Jordan beside Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Balak the son of Zippor saw all that Israel had done to the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moab was filled with much fear because of the people, for they were many. Moab was very afraid of the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moab said to the leaders of Midian, “Now these people will take away everything around us like the bull eats up the grass of the field.” Balak the son of Zippor was king of Moab at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he sent men to Balaam the son of Beor, at Pethor, which is near the River in the land of the children of his people. They said to him, “See, a people came out of Egypt. See, they cover the land, and they are living beside me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now come, I beg you. Curse this people for me, because they are too strong for me. Then I may be able to win the battle against them and send them out of the land. For I know that good will come to the one you pray for, and trouble will come to the one you curse.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the leaders of Moab and the leaders of Midian left with the pay in their hand for the one who tells what will happen in the future. When they came to Balaam, they told him Balak’s words.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to them, “Stay here tonight. I will bring word to you as the Lord may speak to me.” So the leaders of Moab stayed with Balaam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God came to Balaam and said, “Who are these men with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to God, “Balak the son of Zippor, king of Moab, has sent word to me, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘See, the people who came out of Egypt cover the land. Now come, curse them for me. Then I may be able to fight against them and send them away.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to Balaam, “Do not go with them. Do not curse the people, for I have decided that good would come to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Balaam got up in the morning and said to Balak’s leaders, “Return to your land. For the Lord will not let me go with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the leaders of Moab got up and went to Balak, and said, “Balaam would not come with us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak sent leaders again, more than were sent before, and men who were more important.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came to Balaam and said to him, “Balak the son of Zippor says, ‘I beg you, let nothing keep you from coming to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give you much honor. I will do whatever you tell me. I beg you to come and curse these people for me.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam answered and said to Balak’s men, “Balak could give me his house full of silver and gold. But I could not do anything, small or big, against the Word of the Lord my God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I ask you to stay here tonight. I will find out what else the Lord will say to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God came to Balaam at night and said to him, “If the men have come to call you, get up and go with them. But do only what I tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Balaam got up in the morning and got his donkey ready, and went with the leaders of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God was angry because he was going. The angel of the Lord stood in the way against him. Balaam was sitting on his donkey, and his two servants were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the donkey saw the angel of the Lord standing in the way with his sword in his hand, the donkey turned off the road and went into the field. But Balaam hit the donkey to turn her on the road again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord stood in a narrow path in the grape-field, with a wall on each side.
speaker: Narrator

text: The donkey saw the angel of the Lord. So she pushed herself against the wall and crushed Balaam’s foot against it, so he hit her again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord went farther. He stood in a narrow place where there was no way to turn to the right or the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the donkey saw the angel of the Lord, she lay down under Balaam. So Balaam was angry and hit the donkey with his stick.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord opened the mouth of the donkey, and she said to Balaam, “What have I done to you? Why have you hit me these three times?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to the donkey, “Because you have made a fool of me! If there had been a sword in my hand, I would have killed you by now!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The donkey said to Balaam, “Am I not your donkey on which you have traveled all your life to this day? Have I ever done this to you before?” And Balaam said, “No.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord opened Balaam’s eyes, and he saw the angel of the Lord standing in the way with his sword in his hand. And he bowed to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord said to him, “Why have you hit your donkey these three times? See, I have come out against you, because your way was against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the donkey saw me and turned from me these three times. If she had not turned from me, for sure I would have killed you, and let her live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to the angel of the Lord, “I have sinned. For I did not know that you were standing in the way against me. But now, if it does not please you, I will turn back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord said to Balaam, “Go with the men. But speak only what I tell you.” So Balaam went with the leaders of Balak.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak heard that Balaam was coming. He went out to meet him at the city of Moab, on the Arnon, at the far side of the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “Did I not send men to tell you to come? Why did you not come to me? Am I not able to honor you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “See, I have come to you! Am I able to speak anything at all? The Word that God puts in my mouth is what I must speak.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balaam went with Balak, and they came to Kiriathhuzoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak killed bulls and sheep on the altar in worship, and sent some to Balaam and the leaders who were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning Balak took Balaam and brought him up to the high places of Baal. From there he saw part of the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balaam said to Balak, “Build seven altars here for me. And make ready seven bulls and seven rams for me here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak did as Balaam had said. Balak and Balaam gave a bull and a ram on each altar in worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balaam said to Balak, “Stand beside your burnt gift, and I will go. It might be that the Lord will come to me. And whatever He shows me I will tell you.” So he went up to a hill without trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: God met Balaam. Balaam said to Him, “I have made seven altars. And I have given a bull and a ram on each altar in worship.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord put words in Balaam’s mouth, and said, “Return to Balak. This is what you should say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Balaam returned to Balak, and saw him and all the leaders of Moab standing beside his burnt gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam began speaking and said, “Balak the king of Moab has brought me from Aram, from the mountains of the east. ‘Come, curse Jacob for me,’ he said. ‘Come, say that Israel should be punished!’
speaker: Narrator

text: How can I curse those whom God has not cursed? How can I say that those should be punished whom God has not said should be punished?
speaker: Narrator

text: I see Israel from the top of the rocks. I look at them from the hills. See, the people live apart. They will not be thought of as one of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who can number the dust of Jacob, or number the fourth part of Israel? Let me die the death of those who are right and good. Let my end be like theirs!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “What have you done to me? I took you to curse those who hate me. But see, you have asked that good would come to them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam answered, “Must I not be careful to speak what the Lord puts in my mouth?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to him, “I beg you, come with me to another place from where you will see them. But you will only see a part of them and not all of them. Curse them for me from there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took him to the field of Zophim, to the top of Pisgah. He built seven altars and gave a bull and a ram on each altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Stand here beside your burnt gift, while I meet the Lord over there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord met Balaam and put words in his mouth and said, “Return to Balak. This is what you should say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he returned to Balak, and saw him and all the leaders of Moab standing beside his burnt gift. Balak said to him, “What has the Lord said?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balaam began speaking and said, “Rise, O Balak, and hear! Listen to me, O son of Zippor!
speaker: Narrator

text: God is not a man, that He should lie. He is not a son of man, that He should be sorry for what He has said. Has He said, and will He not do it? Has He spoken, and will He not keep His Word?
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I have been told to speak good of Israel. When He has spoken good of them, I cannot change it.
speaker: Narrator

text: No hard times are seen in Jacob. No trouble is seen in Israel. The Lord their God is with them. And the cry of a king is among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: God brings them out of Egypt. He is for them like the horns of the wild bull.
speaker: Narrator

text: For there is no special thing that has been shown against Jacob. Nothing has told of a bad future for Israel. Now it will be said of Jacob and Israel, ‘Look what God has done!’
speaker: Narrator

text: See, people rise like a female lion. It lifts itself like a lion. It will not lie down until it eats the food it has killed, and drinks the blood of the kill.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “Do not curse them at all or pray that good would come to them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Balaam answered Balak, “Did I not tell you that I must do whatever the Lord says?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balak said to Balaam, “I beg you, come. I will take you to another place. It might be that God will be pleased to have you curse them for me from there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Balak took Balaam to the top of Peor which looks over the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Build seven altars for me here. And make ready seven bulls and seven rams for me here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak did just as Balaam had said. He gave a bull and a ram on each altar in worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam saw that it pleased the Lord to speak good of Israel. So he did not go, as at other times, and look for special things to see. Instead he looked toward the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam looked up and saw Israel living in their tents by their families. And the Spirit of God came upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He began speaking and said, “Balaam the son of Beor is the man whose eye is opened.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hears the words of God. He sees what the All-powerful wants him to see. He falls down, but has his eyes open.
speaker: Narrator

text: How fair are your tents, O Jacob, and your homes, O Israel!
speaker: Narrator

text: They are like valleys that spread out, and like gardens beside the river. They are like aloes planted by the Lord, and like cedars beside the waters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Water will flow from his pails. His seed will be by many waters. His king will be more powerful than Agag, and his nation will be honored.
speaker: Narrator

text: God brings him out of Egypt. He is for him like the horns of the wild bull. He will destroy the nations who fight against him. He will crush their bones in pieces and cut through them with his arrows.
speaker: Narrator

text: He bows down. He lies down like a lion. And as a lion, who will wake him? Good will come to everyone who prays for you. And cursed is everyone who curses you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balak’s anger burned against Balaam, and he hit his hands together. Balak said to Balaam, “I called you to curse those who hate me. But see, you have done nothing but pray that good would come to them these three times!
speaker: Narrator

text: So now run away to your place. I said I would give you much honor, but the Lord has kept you from honor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balaam said to Balak, “Did I not tell the men you had sent to me,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Even if Balak were to give me his house full of silver and gold, I cannot do anything against the Word of the Lord’? I said, ‘I cannot do good or bad because I want to. What the Lord says, I will say.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now see, I am going to my people. Come, I will tell you what this people will do to your people in the days to come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he began speaking and said, “Balaam the son of Beor is the man whose eye is opened.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hears the words of God. He knows what the Most High wants him to know. He sees what the All-powerful wants him to see. He falls down, but has his eyes open.
speaker: Narrator

text: I see him, but not now. I see him, but he is not near. A star will come out of Jacob. A special stick of power will rise from Israel. It will crush the forehead of Moab, and break down all the sons of Sheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will take the land of Edom. And it will take the land of Seir, who fights against Israel. And Israel will fight with much power.
speaker: Narrator

text: One from Jacob will rule. He will destroy from the city all who are left alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balaam looked at Amalek and said, “Amalek was the first of the nations. But he will be destroyed in the end.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he looked at the Kenite and said, “The place where you live is strong. Your nest is set in the rock.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Kain will be destroyed. How long will Asshur keep you against your will?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balaam said, “Who can live when God does this?
speaker: Narrator

text: But ships will come from Kittim. They will bring trouble to Asshur and Eber, but they will be destroyed also.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balaam got up and left. He returned to his place, and Balak went on his way.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Israel stayed at Shittim, the people were not faithful to the Lord and began to have sex with the daughters of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: They asked the people of Israel to bring gifts to their gods, and the people ate and bowed down to their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel joined themselves to Baal of Peor, and the Lord was angry with Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Take all the leaders of the people, kill them, and put their bodies in the bright daylight before the Lord. Then the strong anger of the Lord may turn away from Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses said to the judges of Israel, “Each of you kill his men who have joined themselves to Baal of Peor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of the people of Israel came and brought a Midianite woman to his family. Moses and all the people of Israel saw this while they were crying at the door of the meeting tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Phinehas the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron the religious leader, saw it, he rose up from among the people. He took a spear in his hand
speaker: Narrator

text: and went after the man of Israel into the tent. Then he cut through the bodies of both the man of Israel and the woman. So the very bad disease that spread on the people of Israel was stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who died because of this bad disease were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Phinehas the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron the religious leader, has turned My anger away from the people of Israel. He was jealous with My jealousy among them, so I did not destroy the people of Israel in My jealousy.
speaker: Narrator

text: So say to them that I make My agreement of peace with Phinehas.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be an agreement for him and his children after him that they will always be religious leaders, because he was jealous for his God, and did what he was to do to pay for the sin of the people of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the man of Israel who was killed with the Midianite woman was Zimri the son of Salu. He was a leader of a father’s house among the Simeonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the Midianite woman who was killed was Cozbi the daughter of Zur. Zur was the head of the people of a father’s house in Midian.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be angry at the Midianites and fight against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they have brought trouble to you with their false ways. They have fooled you and turned you to the wrong way. They have brought you trouble at Peor with Cozbi, the daughter of the leader of Midian, their sister. She was killed on the day the very bad disease came because of Peor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After the very bad disease came on the people because of Israel’s sin, the Lord said to Moses and Eleazar the son of Aaron the religious leader,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Add the numbers of all the people of Israel who are twenty years old and older, by their fathers’ houses. Number whoever in Israel is able to go to war.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Eleazar the religious leader said to the people in the plains of Moab by the Jordan at Jericho,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Number the people who are twenty years old and older, as the Lord has told Moses.”
Now these were the sons of Israel who came out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben was the first-born son of Israel. Reuben’s sons were the family of the Hanochites from Hanoch, the family of the Palluites from Pallu,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of the Hezronites from Hezron, and the family of the Carmites from Carmi.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of the Reubenites, and their number was 43,730.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliab was the son of Pallu.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Eliab were Nemuel, Dathan and Abiram. These are Dathan and Abiram who were chosen by the people and who joined with Korah to argue against Moses and Aaron. They argued against the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the earth opened its mouth and took them together with Korah, when that group died. The fire destroyed 250 men, and taught others to be careful.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the sons of Korah did not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Simeon by their families were the family of the Nemuelites from Nemuel, the family of the Jaminites from Jamin, the family of the Jachinites from Jachin,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of the Zerahites from Zerah, and the family of the Shaulites from Shaul.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of the Simeonites, 22,200 people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Gad by their families were the family of the Zephonites from Zephon, the family of the Haggites from Haggi, the family of the Shunites from Shuni,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of the Oznites from Ozni, the family of the Erites from Eri,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of the Arodites from Arod, and the family of the Arelites from Areli.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of the sons of Gad. Their number was 40,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Judah were Er and Onan. But Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Judah by their families were the family of the Shelanites from Shelah, the family of the Perezites from Perez, and the family of the Zerahites from Zerah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Perez were the family of the Hezronites from Hezron, and the family of the Hamulites from Hamul.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of Judah. Their number was 76,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Issachar by their families were the family of the Tolaites from Tola, the family of the Punites from Puvah,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of the Jashubites from Jashub, and the family of the Shimronites from Shimron.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of Issachar. Their number was 64,300.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Zebulun by their families were the family of the Seredites from Sered, the family of the Elonites from Elon, and the family of the Jahleelites from Jahleel.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of the Zebulunites. Their number was 60,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Joseph by their families were Manasseh and Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Manasseh were the family of the Machirites from Machir, and the family of the Gileadites from Gilead. Machir was the father of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Gilead were the family of the Iezerites from Iezer, the family of the Helekites from Helek,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of the Asrielites from Asriel, the family of the Shechemites from Shechem,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of the Shemidaites from Shemida, and the family of the Hepherites from Hepher.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hepher’s son Zelophehad had no sons, but only daughters. The names of Zelophehad’s daughters were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah and Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of Manasseh. Their number was 52,700.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Ephraim by their families were the family of the Shuthelaites from Shuthelah, the family of the Becherites from Becher, and the family of the Tahanites from Tahan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Shuthelah were the family of the Eranites from Eran.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of the sons of Ephraim. Their number was 32,500. These are the sons of Joseph by their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Benjamin by their families were the family of the Belaites from Bela, the family of the Ashbelites from Ashbel, the family of the Ahiramites from Ahiram,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of the Shuphamites from Shupham, and the family of the Huphamites from Hupham.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Bela were Ard and Naaman, the family of the Ardites from Ard, and the family of the Naamites from Naaman.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Benjamin by their families. Their number was 45,600.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Dan by their families were the family of the Shuhamites from Shuham. These are the families of Dan by their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of all the families of the Shuhamites was 64,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Asher by their families were the family of the Imnites from Imnah, the family of the Ishvites from Ishvi, and the family of the Beriites from Beriah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Beriah were the family of the Heberites from Heber, and the family of the Malchielites from Malchiel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of Asher’s daughter was Serah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of the sons of Asher. Their number was 53,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Naphtali by their families were the family of the Jahzeelites from Jahzeel, the family of the Gunites from Guni,
speaker: Narrator

text: the family of the Jezerites from Jezer, and the family of the Shillemites from Shillem.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of Naphtali by their families. Their number was 45,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who were numbered of the sons of Israel were 601,730.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The land will be divided among these people by the number of names.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give more land to the larger group. Give less land to the smaller group. Each family should be given land by the number of its people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the land should be divided by drawing names. They will receive their land by the names of the families of their fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land will be divided between the larger and smaller groups by the names that are drawn.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who were numbered of the Levites by their families were the family of the Gershonites from Gershon, the family of the Kohathites from Kohath, and the family of the Merarites from Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families of Levi were the Libnites, the Hebronites, the Mahlites, the Mushites, and the Korahites. Kohath was the father of Amram.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of Amram’s wife was Jochebed, the daughter of Levi. She was born to Levi in Egypt. And she gave birth to Amram’s children, Aaron and Moses and their sister Miriam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron was the father of Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Nadab and Abihu died when they burned fire that was not holy before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of all of their males a month old and older was 23,000. For they were not numbered among the people of Israel, because no land was given to them among the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the people who were numbered by Moses and Eleazar the religious leader. They numbered the sons of Israel in the plains of Moab by the Jordan at Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: But among all these was not one of those numbered by Moses and Aaron the religious leader when the people of Israel were numbered in the Desert of Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had said of them, “For sure they will die in the desert.” There was not a man left of them, except Caleb the son of Jephunneh, and Joshua the son of Nun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then came the daughters of Zelophehad the son of Hepher, the son of Gilead, the son of Machir, the son of Manasseh, from the families of Manasseh the son of Joseph. The names of his daughters were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah and Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They stood in front of Moses and Eleazar the religious leader, and the leaders, and all the people at the door of the meeting tent. The daughters said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Our father died in the desert. He was not one of those who gathered together with Korah against the Lord. But he died for his own sin, and he had no sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why should the name of our father be taken away from his family because he had no son? Give us land among our father’s brothers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses asked the Lord what should be done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The daughters of Zelophehad are right in what they say. Be sure to give them their own land among their father’s brothers. Give them what would have been given to their father.
speaker: Narrator

text: And say to the people of Israel, ‘If a man dies and has no son, then give what belongs to him to his daughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he has no daughter, then give what belongs to him to his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he has no brothers, give what belongs to him to his father’s brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if his father has no brothers, then you must give what belongs to him to the nearest person in his own family and it will be his. This will be a Law to the people of Israel, just as the Lord told Moses.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go up to this mountain of Abarim, and see the land I have given to the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have seen it, you will be buried with your people as Aaron your brother was.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you went against My Word when the people complained in the Desert of Zin. You should have honored Me as holy at the waters in front of their eyes.” (These are the waters of Meribah of Kadesh in the Desert of Zin.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: “May the Lord, the God of the spirits of all flesh, choose a man to lead the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let this man go out and come in before them. Let him lead them out and bring them in. Then the people of the Lord may not be like sheep which have no shepherd.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said to Moses, “Take Joshua the son of Nun, in whom is the Spirit, and lay your hand on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have him stand in front of Eleazar the religious leader and in front of all the people. Let them see you give him the work he must do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give some of your power to him so all the people of Israel will obey him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will stand in front of Eleazar the religious leader, who will learn My will for him by using the Urim. At his word, both he and all the people of Israel will go out and at his word, they will come in.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did just as the Lord told him. He took Joshua and had him stand in front of Eleazar the religious leader, and in front of all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he laid his hands on him and gave him the work he must do, just as the Lord had said through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the people of Israel, ‘Be careful to bring My gift, My food for My gifts by fire, as a pleasing smell to me, at the right time.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And say to them, ‘This is the gift by fire which you must give to the Lord. Give two perfect male lambs one year old, as a burnt gift every day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give one lamb in the morning, and the other lamb in the evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: And give a tenth part of a basket of fine flour for a grain gift, mixed with a fourth part of a jar of beaten oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a burnt gift which was set apart at Mount Sinai as a pleasing smell, a gift by fire always to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its drink gift will be a fourth part of a jar for each lamb. Pour out a drink gift of strong drink to the Lord in the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give the other lamb in the evening. Like the grain gift of the morning, and like its drink gift, you will give it as a gift by fire. It is a pleasing smell to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘On the Day of Rest give a gift of two perfect male lambs one year old. With it give two-tenths part of a basket of fine flour mixed with oil for a grain gift, and its drink gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: The burnt gift of every Day of Rest is to be added to the burnt gift which is always given and its drink gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then you must give a burnt gift to the Lord at the beginning of your months. Give two bulls, one ram, and seven male lambs one year old that are perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give three-tenths part of a basket of fine flour mixed with oil for a grain gift for each bull. Give two-tenths part of fine flour mixed with oil for a grain gift for the one ram.
speaker: Narrator

text: And give a tenth part of a basket of fine flour mixed with oil for a grain gift for each lamb. They are to be given for a burnt gift of a pleasing smell, a gift by fire to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their drink gifts will be half a jar of wine for a bull, a third of a jar for the ram, and a fourth part of a jar for a lamb. This is the burnt gift of each month for all the months of the year.
speaker: Narrator

text: And give one male goat for a sin gift to the Lord. It will be given with its drink gift, besides each day’s burnt gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The fourteenth day of the first month will be the Lord’s Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: A special supper will be on the fifteenth day of this month. Bread without yeast will be eaten for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day will be a holy gathering. You must do no hard work.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will give a gift by fire, a burnt gift to the Lord. It will be two bulls, one ram, and seven perfect male lambs one year old.
speaker: Narrator

text: And give fine flour mixed with oil for their grain gift. Give three-tenths part of a basket for a bull, two-tenths part for a ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and a tenth part of a basket for each of the seven lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then give one male goat for a sin gift, to pay for your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give these besides the burnt gift of the morning, which is each day’s burnt gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give the food of the gift by fire in this way each day for seven days, as a pleasing smell to the Lord. Give it with its drink gift, besides each day’s burnt gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: And on the seventh day you will have a holy gathering. You must do no hard work.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You will have a holy gathering on the day of the first-fruits also. This is when you will bring a gift of new grain to the Lord in your Special Supper of Weeks. You must do no hard work.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you will give for a pleasing smell to the Lord a burnt gift of two young bulls, one ram, and seven male lambs one year old.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give fine flour mixed with oil for their grain gift. Give three-tenths part of a basket for each bull, two-tenths part for the one ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and a tenth part for each of the seven lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: And give one male goat to pay for your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: These gifts should be besides each day’s burnt gift and its grain gift. Give them with their drink gifts. The animals must be perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You will have a holy gathering on the first day of the seventh month. You must do no hard work. It is a day for you to blow the horns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give as a pleasing smell to the Lord a burnt gift of one bull, one ram, and seven male lambs one year old, all are to be perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: And give fine flour mixed with oil for their grain gift. Give three-tenths part of a basket for the bull, two-tenths part for the ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and one-tenth part for each of the seven lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then give one male goat for a sin gift, to pay for your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: These gifts should be besides the burnt gift of the new moon, and its grain gift, and each day’s burnt gift and its grain gift, and their drink gifts. It must be done by the Law, for a pleasing smell, a gift by fire to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You will have a holy gathering on the tenth day of this seventh month, and be without pride. You must not do any work.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will give to the Lord as a pleasing smell a burnt gift of one bull, one ram, and seven male lambs one year old, all are to be perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: And give fine flour mixed with oil for their grain gift. Give three-tenths part of a basket for the bull, two-tenths part for the one ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and a tenth part for each of the seven lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then give one male goat for a sin gift, besides the sin gift to pay for sins, each day’s burnt gift and its grain gift, and their drink gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You will have a holy gathering on the fifteenth day of the seventh month. You must do no hard work, and you will have a special supper to the Lord for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will give a burnt gift of thirteen bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs one year old that are perfect. They will be a gift by fire, a pleasing smell to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And give fine flour mixed with oil for their grain gift. Give three-tenths part of a basket for each of the thirteen bulls, two-tenths part for each of the two rams,
speaker: Narrator

text: and a tenth part for each of the fourteen lambs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then give one male goat for a sin gift, besides each day’s burnt gift, its grain gift and its drink gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Then on the second day give twelve bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs one year old that are perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: And give their grain gifts and drink gifts for the number of bulls, rams and lambs, by the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give one male goat for a sin gift, besides each day’s burnt gift and its grain gift, and their drink gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘On the third day give eleven bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs one year old that are perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give their grain gifts and drink gifts for the number of bulls, rams and lambs, by the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then give one male goat for a sin gift, besides each day’s burnt gift and its grain gift and drink gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘On the fourth day give ten bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs one year old that are perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give their grain gifts and drink gifts for the number of bulls, rams and lambs, by the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then give one male goat for a sin gift, besides each day’s burnt gift, its grain gift and drink gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘On the fifth day give nine bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs one year old that are perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give their grain gifts and drink gifts for the number of bulls, rams and lambs, by the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then give one male goat for a sin gift, besides each day’s burnt gift and its grain gift and drink gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘On the sixth day give eight bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs one year old that are perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give their grain gifts and drink gifts for the number of bulls, rams and lambs, by the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then give one male goat for a sin gift, besides each day’s burnt gift, its grain gift and drink gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘On the seventh day give seven bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs one year old that are perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give their grain gifts and drink gifts for the number of bulls, rams and lambs, by the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then give one male goat for a sin gift, besides each day’s burnt gift, its grain gift and drink gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You will have a religious gathering on the eighth day. You must do no hard work.
speaker: Narrator

text: But give a burnt gift of one bull, one ram, and seven male lambs one year old that are perfect. It will be a gift by fire, a pleasing smell to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give their grain gifts and drink gifts for the bull, the ram and lambs, for their number, by the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then give one male goat for a sin gift, besides each day’s burnt gift and its grain gift and drink gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Give these to the Lord at the times given, besides your promised gifts and your free-will gifts. They will be for your burnt gifts, your grain gifts, your drink gifts and for your peace gifts.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the people of Israel all that the Lord had told him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to the heads of the families of the sons of Israel, “This is what the Lord has said.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man makes a promise to the Lord, or swears that he will keep his promise, he must not break his word. He must do all that he said he would do.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a woman makes a promise to the Lord, and swears to keep her promise in her father’s house when she is young,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if her father hears her promise and how she has sworn to keep it, and says nothing to her, then all her promises must be kept. She must keep every promise she has sworn to keep.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her father does not allow her to keep her promise on the day he hears of it, then she does not need to keep any of the promises she has sworn to keep. The Lord will forgive her because her father would not allow it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If she gets married and has promises to keep because of what she swore without thinking,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if her husband hears of it and says nothing to her on the day he hears, then she must keep the promises she has sworn to keep.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if on the day he hears of it, her husband does not allow her to keep her promise, then she will not have to keep the promise that she had sworn to keep when she was not thinking. The Lord will forgive her.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A woman whose husband has died or left her must keep the promises she has sworn to keep.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if she has made a promise in her husband’s house, and she has sworn to keep a promise there
speaker: Narrator

text: and if her husband hears of it, and does not go against her or say anything to her, then she must keep all the promises she had sworn to keep.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her husband does not allow her to keep her promises on the day he hears of them, then she does not have to keep the promises she had sworn to keep. If her husband will not let her keep them, the Lord will forgive her.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Her husband has the right to have her keep, or not keep, any promise she has sworn to keep.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her husband says nothing to her from day to day, then she must keep all her promises. He made her promises so they could not be changed, because he said nothing to her on the day he heard of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he will not allow her to keep her promises after he has heard of them, then her guilt will be on him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the Laws which the Lord told Moses, between a man and his wife, and between a father and his daughter, while she is young and in her father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Punish the Midianites for the people of Israel. After that you will be buried with your people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to the people, “Take men from among you and make them ready for war against Midian. They will punish Midian for the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Send to the war 1,000 men from each of all the family groups of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So 1,000 men came from each of the family groups of the thousands of Israel. There were 12,000 ready for war.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent them, 1,000 from each family group, to the war. Phinehas the son of Eleazar the religious leader went to the war with them. In his hand were the holy objects and the horns for blowing the sound of coming danger.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men made war against Midian, just as the Lord had told Moses, and they killed every male.
speaker: Narrator

text: They killed the five kings of Midian with the sword also, Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba. And they also killed Balaam the son of Beor with the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel took the women of Midian and their little ones, and all their cattle, all their flocks, and all the good things that belonged to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they burned all their cities where they lived and all their tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took all that was left of both man and animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they brought the people they had taken and the animals and whatever belonged to them to Moses, and to Eleazar the religious leader, and to the people of Israel. Their tents were on the plains of Moab by the Jordan near Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Eleazar the religious leader and all the leaders of the people went out from the tents to meet them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was angry with the leaders of the army, the heads of thousands and the heads of hundreds, who had fought in the war.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Have you allowed all the women to live?
speaker: Narrator

text: See, these women listened to Balaam and caused the people of Israel to sin against the Lord in what happened at Peor. So the very bad disease came to the people of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now kill every male among the little ones, and kill every woman who has had a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: But keep alive for yourselves all the girls who have not had a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stay away from the tents for seven days. If you have killed any person or have touched any dead body, you must make yourself and those you have taken clean, on the third day and on the seventh day.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must clean every piece of clothing, everything made of leather, everything made of goats’ hair, and everything made of wood.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eleazar the religious leader said to the men of war who had gone to battle, “This is the Law which the Lord has told Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take the gold, silver, brass, iron, tin and lead,
speaker: Narrator

text: everything that can last through fire. Pass it through the fire, and it will be clean. But it must be made pure with the water for cleaning. Whatever cannot last through fire you must pass through the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must wash your clothes on the seventh day, and you will be clean. Then you may come among the tents.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “You and Eleazar the religious leader and the heads of the fathers’ houses of the people should number all that was taken from the battle, both of man and animal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Divide what was taken between the men of war who went to battle and all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then take a tax for the Lord from the men of war who went out to battle. Take one out of 500 of the persons and the cattle and the donkeys and the sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take this from their half and give it to Eleazar the religious leader, as a gift to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the half belonging to the people of Israel, take one out of every fifty of the persons and cattle and donkeys and sheep and all the animals. Give them to the Levites who take care of the meeting tent of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Eleazar the religious leader did just as the Lord had told Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: What was left from that which the men of war had taken was 675,000 sheep,
speaker: Narrator

text: 72,000 cattle,
speaker: Narrator

text: 61,000 donkeys,
speaker: Narrator

text: and 32,000 persons in all, of women who had never had a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: The half taken by those who went out to war was 337,500 sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s tax was 675 sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were 36,000 cattle, from which the Lord’s tax was seventy-two.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were 30,500 donkeys, from which the Lord’s tax was sixty-one.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there were 16,000 persons, from whom the Lord’s tax was thirty-two.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses gave the tax, which was the Lord’s gift, to Eleazar the religious leader, just as the Lord had told Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses divided the people of Israel’s half from the men who had gone to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people’s half was 337,500 sheep,
speaker: Narrator

text: 36,000 cattle,
speaker: Narrator

text: 30,500 donkeys,
speaker: Narrator

text: and 16,000 persons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took one out of every fifty of both man and animal from the people of Israel’s half. He gave them to the Levites, who took care of the meeting tent of the Lord, just as the Lord had told Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the leaders of the thousands of the army, the heads of thousands and the heads of hundreds, came to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Your servants have numbered the men of war whom we lead. Not one man is missing from us.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have brought as a gift to the Lord what each man found, objects of gold, things to be worn on the arms and fingers and ears and necks. They are to pay for our sins before the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Eleazar the religious leader took the gold from them, all the objects made of beaten gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the gold of the gift they gave to the Lord from the heads of thousands and the heads of hundreds was worth 16,750 gold pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the men of war had taken things from the battle, every man for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Eleazar the religious leader took the gold from the heads of thousands and of hundreds. They brought it to the meeting tent so that the people of Israel would be remembered before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the sons of Reuben and the sons of Gad had very many cattle. And they saw that the land of Jazer and the land of Gilead was a good place for cattle.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the sons of Gad and the sons of Reuben came and said to Moses and Eleazar the religious leader and the leaders of the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Ataroth, Dibon, Jazer, Nimrah, Heshbon, Elealeh, Sebam, Nebo and Beon,
speaker: Narrator

text: the land which the Lord won in battle in front of the people of Israel, is a land for cattle and your servants have cattle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said, “If we have found favor in your eyes, let this land be given to your servants as our own. Do not take us to the other side of the Jordan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said to the sons of Gad and the sons of Reuben, “Should your brothers go to war while you sit here?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why do you take from the people of Israel the desire to cross over into the land the Lord has given them?
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what your fathers did when I sent them from Kadesh-barnea to see the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went up to the valley of Eshcol and saw the land. Then they took the desire away from the people of Israel so that they did not go into the land the Lord had given them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord’s anger burned on that day, and He swore, saying
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘None of the men who came up from Egypt, twenty years old and older, will see the land I promised to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob. For they did not follow Me with all their heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only Caleb the son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite and Joshua the son of Nun will see it. For they have followed the Lord with all their hearts.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord’s anger burned against Israel. He made them travel in the desert forty years, until all the people of that day who had sinned in the eyes of the Lord were destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now see, you have grown up in your fathers’ place, children of sinful men. You add still more to the burning anger of the Lord against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if you turn away from following Him, He will leave them in the desert again and you will destroy all these people.”
speaker: Narrator
